questions.question:
Question 1: A 30-year-old woman is being evaluated for chronic headaches, infertility, and galactorrhea. 
MRI of the brain shows the following finding. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
This clinical scenario and brain MRI showing a pituitary adenoma are suggestive of a lactotroph 
adenoma (prolactinoma). 1130 
Sold by @itachibot Pituitary adenomas are usually found in adults. The most common genetic alterations in this 
condition are mutations in G proteins (particularly GNAS). Depending on their size, they are classified as: • Microadenomas - diameter < 1 cm • Macroadenomas - diameter > 1 cm They may be functioning or non-functioning. The most common type of functioning 
pituitary adenomas are prolactinomas. The clinical features of prolactinoma include: • Due to mass effect - • Features of raised intracranial tension • Visual field disturbances (bitemporal hemianopia) - due to compression of optic chiasm • Hypopituitarism - due to compressed hypophyseal stalk • Due to hyperprolactinemia - • Galactorrhoea • Amenorrhoea or oligomenorrhoea • Infertility • Loss of libido • Gynecomastia Serum prolactin concentrations tend to correlate with the size of the adenoma. The normal range 
of serum prolactin is 5-20 g/L. The diagnosis of prolactinoma is most likely to be associated with 
a prolactin level >200 g/L.

questions.question:
Question 2: Presence of which of the following features is required to diagnose a patient with pituitary 
carcinoma?
questions.explanation:
The following features are required for the diagnosis of pituitary carcinoma: • A pituitary tumor that has metastasized to distant sites, either craniospinal or systemic sites 
(and/or) • Presence of a pituitary tumor that is not contiguous with the primary sellar tumour Pituitary carcinoma is extremely rare (< 1% of total tumors). They are associated with activating 
mutations of the HRAS oncogene. The diagnosis of pituitary carcinoma cannot be made based on histologic appearance alone. 
Though pituitary adenomas normally show cellular monomorphism and the absence of a reticulin 
network, they can have some overlapping features with malignant tumors such as: • Atypical adenomas - show pleomorphism and atypical mitosis • Invasive adenomas - • Non-encapsulated 1131 
Sold by @itachibot • Show local invasion into cavernous and sphenoid sinuses, dura, brain • However, they remain confined to the primary tumor site

questions.question:
Question 3: 1125 
Sold by @itachibot Which of the following cells secrete parathyroid hormone?
questions.explanation:
Parathyroid hormone (PTH) is secreted by the chief cells of the parathyroid glands. The function of the parathyroids is to regulate calcium homeostasis. This gland is composed of 
two cell types: • Chief cells - • Polygonal cells with uniform nuclei and pink cytoplasm • Water-clear appearance - due to presence of large amounts of cytoplasmic glycogen • Secretory granules containing PTH • Oxyphil cells - Slightly larger cells with acidophilic cytoplasm with no known function. The following image shows the normal histology of the parathyroid gland: 1132 
Sold by @itachibot C-cells or parafollicular cells are present in the thyroid. They secrete calcitonin.

questions.question: Question 4: What is the most common cause of asymptomatic hypercalcemia?
questions.explanation:
The most common cause of asymptomatic hypercalcemia (isolated hypercalcemia without signs or 
symptoms) is primary hyperparathyroidism. It is also the most common cause of hypercalcemia 
overall. Primary hyperparathyroidism results in autonomous overproduction of parathyroid hormone 
(PTH), resulting in elevated levels. It usually results from an adenoma or hyperplasia of 
parathyroid tissue. The most common cause of symptomatic hypercalcemia is malignancy. The most common 
mechanism through which osteolytic tumors induce hypercalcemia is the secretion of the 
PTH-related peptide (PTHrP).

questions.question:
Question 5: A 40-year-old woman presented with bone pain and abdominal cramps for the past 1 week. 
She has had multiple prior hospital admissions for management of recurrent renal calculi. 
Investigations revealed elevated serum calcium and PTH levels with reduced phosphate 
levels. Which of the following is the most common pathological change responsible for this 
condition?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical picture is highly suggestive of primary hyperparathyroidism. The most common 
cause is a sporadic, solitary parathyroid adenoma. Parathyroid tumors may be associated with cyclin D1 gene inversions and MEN1 
mutations. Hyperparathyroidism refers to elevated parathyroid hormone (PTH). It is classified 
into: • Primary - autonomous overproduction of PTH • Secondary - compensatory hypersecretion of PTH in response to prolonged hypocalcemia • Tertiary - persistent hypersecretion of PTH even after correction of prolonged hypocalcemia. 
(e.g. after renal transplant) 1133 
Sold by @itachibot The classical symptoms and signs of primary hyperparathyroidism are due to hypercalcemia as 
well as increased parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels. The features of hypercalcemia are as follows: The features of elevated PTH levels are as follows: • Osteitis fibrosa cystica • Osteopenia/osteoporosis • Hyperuricemia and gout • Pseudogout • Increased production of calcitriol • Nephrolithiasis • Hypophosphatemia • Anemia The clinical signs associated with primary hyperparathyroidism can be remembered with the

questions.question:
Question 6: A 47-year-old woman was evaluated for chronic backache and abdominal pain. Investigations 
revealed the following. What is the most likely bone finding seen in this condition?
questions.explanation:
The clinical scenario and lab findings point towards a diagnosis of hyperparathyroidism. The bone 
finding associated with this condition is osteitis fibrosa cystica. This condition is also called brown tumor or von Recklinghausen disease of bone. 1134 
Sold by @itachibot In hyperparathyroidism, high levels of PTH result in increased osteoclast activity. This results in 
bone loss which predisposes to microfractures and secondary hemorrhages. This results in the 
following changes: • An influx of macrophages that form giant cells • Mass of reparative fibrous tissue • Increased vascularity, hemorrhage, and hemosiderin deposition - results in brown color The image given below is showing a brown tumor with numerous giant cells with interstitial 
hemorrhage, hemosiderin. Option A: Osteoporosis circumscripta is a large, well-defined lytic lesion seen in the skull of 
patients with Paget's disease. Option B: Fraying and cupping of the metaphysis of the bones are classically seen in patients 
suffering from rickets. Option D: Punched out lytic lesions of the bone are seen in patients with multiple myeloma.

questions.question:
Question 7: A 46-year-old woman is referred with recurrent episodes of hypoglycemia. During the 
evaluation, she is found to have high serum levels of insulin. Measurement of which of the 
following can help in reaching the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of hypoglycemia due to hyperinsulinemia. As C-peptide is a 
marker of endogenous insulin secretion, its levels would help in identifying the source of insulin: • High C-peptide - excess insulin production (insulinoma) • Normal/ low C-peptide - exogenous insulin administration (factitious disorder) The precursor molecule of insulin is pre-proinsulin, which gets cleaved to form proinsulin. This 
proinsulin gets cleaved to form insulin and C-peptide (by-product). Hence, both are secreted in 
equimolar quantities during insulin secretion. Hence, the level of C-peptide corresponds to the 
level of endogenous insulin. The levels of C-peptide decrease with the loss of  -cell mass in type 1 diabetes. 1135 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 8: Patients with which of the following chromosomal anomalies are least likely to develop 
diabetes mellitus?
questions.explanation: Edward's syndrome or trisomy 18 is not associated with diabetes mellitus. Genetic syndromes associated with diabetes mellitus include: • Down's syndrome (trisomy 21) • Klinefelter's syndrome (XXY karyotype) • Turner's syndrome (XO karyotype) • Prader–Willi syndrome (deletion of paternal chromosome 15) Other causes of diabetes mellitus include: • Genetic defects in insulin action - • Type A insulin resistance • Lipoatrophic diabetes • Exocrine pancreatic defects - • Chronic pancreatitis • Pancreatectomy/trauma • Neoplasia • Cystic fibrosis • Hemochromatosis • Fibrocalculous pancreatopathy • Endocrinopathies - • Acromegaly • Cushing syndrome • Hyperthyroidism • Pheochromocytoma • Glucagonoma • Infections - • Cytomegalovirus • Coxsackie B virus • Congenital rubella

questions.question:
Question 9: A pathologist is studying a Congo red-stained slide of pancreatic tissue. He observes it under 
polarized light and notes the following finding. This finding is commonly associated with 
which of the following conditions? 1127 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
1136 
Sold by @itachibot The image shows a Congo red-stained biopsy specimen with apple-green birefringence under 
polarized microscopy. It is indicative of amyloid accumulation within the pancreatic islets. This 
is commonly associated with type 2 diabetes mellitus. Amyloid deposition begins in and around capillaries and between cells. In advanced stages, the 
islets may be virtually obliterated and fibrosis may also be observed.

questions.question:
Question 10: Which of the following is not a detrimental effect of advanced glycation end-products in 
patients suffering from diabetes mellitus?

options.a: Deposition of excess basement membrane material due to TGF- release
options.b: Generation of reactive oxygen species in endothelial cells
options.c: Increased anticoagulant effect on endothelial cells and macrophages
options.d: Increase in vascular smooth muscle cells and extracellular matrix

questions.explanation:
Advanced glycation end products (AGEs) result in increased procoagulant effects on endothelial 
cells and macrophages, not anticoagulant effects. AGEs are formed by nonenzymatic reactions between intracellular glucose-derived dicarbonyl 
precursors with the amino groups of proteins. They bind to a specific receptor (RAGE) that is 
expressed on inflammatory cells (macrophages and T cells), endothelium, and vascular smooth 
muscle. The detrimental effects of the AGE-RAGE signalling axis within the vascular compartment 
include: • Release of cytokines and growth factors, including TGF- - leads to deposition of excess 
basement membrane material • Generation of reactive oxygen species in endothelial cells. • Increased procoagulant activity on endothelial cells and macrophages. • Enhanced proliferation of vascular smooth muscle cells and synthesis of extracellular matrix These effects are responsible for the microvascular and macrovascular complications in diabetes 
mellitus.

questions.question: Question 11: What is the most common pancreatic endocrine neoplasm?
questions.explanation:
Insulinoma ( -cell tumors) is the most common pancreatic endocrine neoplasm. It produces 
sufficient insulin to induce clinically significant hypoglycemia. The three most common and distinctive clinical syndromes associated with functional pancreatic 
endocrine neoplasms are as follows: • Hyperinsulinism • Zollinger–Ellison syndrome (hypergastrinemia) • Multiple endocrine neoplasias (MEN)

questions.question:
Question 12: A 39-year-old man was referred to a higher center for further evaluation of peptic ulcer 
disease refractory to high doses of proton pump inhibitors. There is a history of pituitary and 
parathyroid tumors in his family members. Serum gastrin level was found to be 1690 pg/ml 
(normal < 100) and a neuroendocrine tumor is suspected. Which of the following is false 
about this condition?

options.a: It is associated with intractable jejunal ulcers
options.b: This patient likely has a solitary tumor
options.d: Tumors usually originate in Passaro's triangle

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a gastrin-producing tumor or gastrinoma 
(Zollinger-Ellison syndrome). The family history of pituitary and parathyroid tumors is suggestive 1137 
Sold by @itachibot of MEN1 syndrome. This syndrome is associated with multifocal gastrinomas. On the other hand, sporadic gastrinomas are usually single. Gastrinomas usually arise in the duodenum, peripancreatic soft tissues, pancreas. The site of 
origin is the duodenum when ZES is associated with MEN1. Most tumors are locally invasive and 
metastasize early. Hypergastrinemia gives rise to extreme gastric acid secretion and peptic ulceration, that is 
refractory to proton pump inhibitors. It results in multiple ulcers in duodenum, stomach, and 
uncommon areas like jejunum.

questions.question:
Question 13: A patient with longstanding diabetes mellitus came with complaints of bulky stools. 
Ultrasound abdomen showed the presence of multiple gallstones. Hypersecretion of which of 
the following leads to this presentation?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario is suggestive of a -cell tumor or somatostatinoma. It results in hypersecretion 
of somatostatin. Somatostatin inhibits pancreatic and biliary secretions. Patients with somatostatinoma usually 
present with vague abdominal pain along with the triad of: • Gallstones - due to bile stasis • Diabetes mellitus - due to inhibition of insulin secretion • Steatorrhea - due to inhibition of pancreatic exocrine secretion and bile secretion

questions.question:
Question 14: A patient presented with profuse watery diarrhoea and muscle cramps for the past few weeks. 
The diarrhoea was intractable to antibiotics and stool culture was negative for organisms. He 
also complained of indigestion and frequent bloating. On investigation, he was found to have 
microcytic hypochromic anaemia. Serum potassium was 2.4 mmol/L. Upper GI endoscopy 
was normal. Excess of which of the following hormones leads to this condition?

options.a: Lymphocytic infiltration in the retroorbital space

questions.explanation:
The given scenario is suggestive of WDHA syndrome. It is due to hypersecretion of VIP 
(vasoactive-intestinal peptide). WDHA syndrome includes the following features: • Watery diarrhea • Hypokalemia (Serum K+< 3.5 mmol/L) • Achlorhydria (bloating, indigestion, iron deficiency) Neural crest tumors, such as neuroblastomas, ganglioneuroblastoma, ganglioneuromas, and 
pheochromocytomas can also be associated with VIPoma syndrome. 1138 
Sold by @itachibot Thyroid Glands
